definitions.definition: the red liquid that flows through the bodies of humans and animals

examples.text: He lost a lot of blood in the accident.
Blood was pouring out of a cut on her head.
His hands were **covered in blood**.
to **give blood** *(= to have blood taken from you so that it can be used in the medical treatment of other people)*
After the attacks, people **donated blood** in record numbers.
He was a hot-headed warrior, always too quick to **shed blood** *(= attack and injure or kill somebody)*.
to **draw blood** *(= to wound a person so that they lose blood)*
a **drop/pool of blood**
There was dried blood on her cheek.
a **blood cell/sample**
to improve **blood flow** to the heart
the blood supply to the brain
The heart pumps blood around the body.
He rubbed his limbs vigorously to get the blood circulating.
Blood oozed slowly from the corner of his mouth.
My handkerchief was soaked in blood from my nose.
He was lying on the floor, covered in blood.
I felt the blood coursing in my veins as I ran.
The blood drummed in her ears.
The blood drained from his face when I told him the news.
The blood rushed to her face as she realized her error.
Blood spattered the seats of the vehicle.
The body lay in a pool of blood.
The dog's fur was caked in blood when we found him.
The hospital appealed for more people to donate blood.
Traces of an illegal substance were found in his blood.

definitions.definition: having the type of blood mentioned

examples.text: cold-blooded reptiles

definitions.definition: family origins

examples.text: She is of noble blood.
There is some Polish blood on his father's side.
I doubt if I have a single drop of aristocratic blood in my veins.

definitions.definition: a rich and fashionable man

examples.text: a young blood

definitions.definition: feelings of hate or strong dislike
to be angry with somebody and want to hurt or punish them
to be a natural part of your character and of the character of other members of your family
family relationships are stronger than any others
somebody is very angry and ready to argue or fight
very hard work; a lot of effort

examples.text: The only way to succeed is through old-fashioned blood, sweat and tears.

definitions.definition: when you say that somebody is flesh and blood, you mean that they are a normal human with needs, emotions and weaknesses

examples.text: Listening to the cries was more than flesh and blood could stand.
She wasn't a ghost. She was flesh and blood.

definitions.definition: a person that you are related to

examples.text: You can’t do that to your own flesh and blood!

definitions.definition: to make you extremely frightened or shocked
to be responsible for somebody’s death

examples.text: a dictator with the blood of thousands on his hands

definitions.definition: acting in a way that is deliberately cruel

examples.text: to kill somebody in cold blood

definitions.definition: almost impossible to obtain

examples.text: Getting an apology from him was like getting blood from a stone.

definitions.definition: to make somebody extremely angry

examples.text: The way he treats his employees really makes my blood boil.

definitions.definition: to make somebody very frightened or fill them with horror

examples.text: The sound of laughter in the empty house made my blood run cold.
Our blood ran cold at the thought of how easily we could have been killed.

definitions.definition: new members or employees, especially young ones, with new ideas or ways of doing things

examples.text: This company badly needs to bring in some new blood.

definitions.definition: to kill or wound somebody

examples.text: Nothing can justify spilling innocent blood.

definitions.definition: to show that you are very angry; to speak in an angry way

examples.text: She looked at him with eyes that spat venom.
She surveyed him coldly with eyes that spat venom.

definitions.definition: to make somebody excited

examples.text: The atmosphere in a theatre never failed to stir her blood.

definitions.definition: to work very hard

examples.text: I sweated blood to get everything ready in time.

wordOrigin: Old English blōd, of Germanic origin; related to German Blut and Dutch bloed.
